content.webTitle: WA premier flags communities review but fails to meet Indigenous leaders

fields.headline: WA premier flags communities review but fails to meet Indigenous leaders
fields.bodyText: The Western Australian premier Colin Barnett has revealed details of a review of WA’s remote Aboriginal communities on the same day he declined to meet with Aboriginal leaders to discuss the threatened closure of those communities. Barnett made the comments to PerthNow on Thursday morning, the same time as a meeting of the alliance of WA land councils in Broome. Aboriginal land councils used the meeting to insist that Aboriginal people be given a say in issues like the remote community closures, declaring in a joint statement that “governments cannot decide where Aboriginal people live in Western Australia”. Barnett was invited to attend that meeting but declined due to “prior commitments”. He told PerthNow that a “comprehensive look” at the viability of remote Aboriginal communities was “under way” and he expected it to uncover evidence of “abuse”. “I won’t walk away from this issue, I will probably get criticised, but there will be evidence come about appalling mistreatment of little kids,” he said. “I, as premier, cannot sit by and let that happen.” But he said the “comprehensive look” would not result in a report. “I’m not into reports, that’s not my style.” Barnett said in November that between 100 and 150 of the state’s 282 remote Aboriginal communities may be forced to close, after the federal government handed responsibility for the communities to the state, along with $90m, which is the equivalent of two years’ funding. He told PerthNow that “maybe the word ‘closure’ … wasn’t the right word,” but said that government support for some of the communities would not continue. “We want to see Aboriginal people succeed, we want to see their children have a safe life and a fair chance at life through a good education,” he said. “That cannot happen in remote tiny communities, it cannot.” “We’ll consult, there’s not going to be a bulldozer-type mentality, and we’re going to determine which communities continue to get those municipal services, and probably better services, but it’s not going to be 282.” “Bulldozer-type mentality” is not a metaphor in the Kimberley – in September the WA government began demolishing buildings left in Oombulgurri, an eastern Kimberley community that was forcibly closed in 2011. Labor Perth MP Alannah MacTiernan said the federal funding only applied to about 160 of WA’s remote communities. A spokesman for the Kimberley Land Council said a number of communities were self-sufficient and have not received any government assistance in years. Barnett’s comments appeared to contradict the conciliatory tone taken by the regional development minister Terry Redman, who did attend the meeting and spoke to Guardian Australia and other media in Broome. Redman said cutting off the services to up to 150 communities was not the government’s current position, and he refused to use the word “closure”. But he was unable to assure Aboriginal leaders that all of WA’s remote Aboriginal communities would remain open and supported by the state. He said “the current circumstances” of remote Aboriginal communities in WA were “unacceptable” in terms of their health, education and employment outcomes, and that addressing that required a “very planned, very strategic response” from government, standing shoulder to shoulder with Aboriginal people. “I’m not sure whether there will or won’t be community closures,” Redman said. “But I know that in some that I’ve been into, conditions are unacceptable. “And I think, certainly one community that I saw, I wouldn’t support it in any way with investment.” Redman said that investment could include funding from the $1bn Royalties for Regions fund. It is not the first time there’s been separation between Redman and Barnett on this policy. Barnett hosed down reports of Redman’s initial suggestion of tying the Royalties for Regions fund to outcome-based projects in remote Aboriginal communities, but did say it may be appropriate to fund water and power services. Redman refused to say whether he agreed with Barnett’s approach to the issue and instead referred to the cabinet approval process, saying, “I’m not going to share with anyone our discussions within government, and certainly between ministers and the premier, about how to take these issues forward.” He said the state would not “force anyone out” and the response of the land councils had been “pleasing”. “I can see how a little uncertainty, with a little bit of information, has drawn some concerns,” he said. Land council members who spoke to Guardian Australia said that uncertainty remained. In a statement released at the close of the meeting on Thursday the group said Aboriginal people should be given a “real say in the issues that affect their lives and wellbeing”. The Kimberley Land Council chairman Anthony Watson said Barnett’s decision not to attend the meeting was “extremely disappointing”. Speaking on behalf of the land councils, Watson said it was good that Redman had said he wanted to engage with Aboriginal people, but it was unfortunate it had taken four months to get to that stage. He said that despite the government’s claims it was consulting, Thursday was the first time a government minister had formally consulted with the peak bodies. “It is disappointing that they have taken so long to get back to us,” he said. “We don’t want another Oombulgurri.” Watson said that as far as he was concerned, there had been “no changes” in the message from government, and that up to 150 communities could still be shut down or have their essential services cut off. “We don’t have the indication of what community is going to be targeted, so we’re still guessing,” he said. “The minister came up here today (and) … didn’t get to bring any information about what the premier is telling him to do, so it’s frustrating that we still haven’t got that information.” Labor Broome MLA Josie Farrer, Nationals MLA Jacqui Boydell and opposition Aboriginal affairs spokesman Ben Wyatt also addressed the meeting. Farrer, a Lungka-Gidja woman, told Guardian Australia that some remote communities in Western Australia did have a history of social problems or mismanagement, but that starving those communities of funding was not the solution. “This is why we have these high number of homeless people in the Broome area – because without a community, they have nowhere to go,” she said.
